SENTENCE.STRING: , promoted for the past year by the ubiquitous Harry Connick Jr., has gone incognito to pitch
newest calling plan.
that lost 60,000 customers in North Carolina last year introduced the new plan Tuesday with advertising that deliberately omitted
name.
has been running 14 billboards in Raleigh and Durham since last week that pose the question: "Who will your 10 be?"
Six area television stations have run similar ads.
On Tuesday,
name was plastered on the billboards to clear up the mystery.
The "10" refers to the new plan, which allows customers unlimited calling to 10 people outside
network.
Typically, such out-of-network calls use up calling time or cost more.
new TV ads are airing today.
The new plan and ad campaign take place against an increasingly bleak financial situation for the Berwyn, Pa., company.
ran into technical problems last year when
tried to switch more than 211,000 AT&T Wireless customers in North Carolina to
network.
acquired them as part of a customer swap with Cingular Wireless.
could transfer only 150,000 of the customers to
network and billing system.
Thousands of customers complained of dead phones, lost e-mail, billing inaccuracies and other headaches.
says
is now gaining customers faster than
losing them, but
growth belies underlying troubles.
Last month,
said
would report lower-than-expected revenues per subscriber, higher-than-expected expenses to acquire and retain subscribers, and increased bad debt expenses in the fourth quarter of 2005.
also said
would delay reporting
annual earnings in March by two weeks to give auditors more time to complete their work.
And
said
situation has become so unstable
would stop providing earnings projections to Wall Street analysts.
"They need relief from their debt holders, or else the company risks filing for bankruptcy," said analyst Michael Nelson of the Stanford Group in Houston.
"I would certainly say they're in a crisis right now."
During the third quarter last year, 3.8 percent of
customers defected, followed by 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter, which compares to an industry average defection rate of 2.1 percent, Nelson said.

PARTICIPANTS-REFEX.REFEX: The marketing and retention division of the c

SENTENCE.STRING: is spending about $450 per customer on promotions and other costs to acquire new customers, compared to an estimated industry average of about $310 per customer, Nelson said.
has 965,822 customers in the Carolinas, Tennessee, Georgia, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
new calling plan, Mobile-to-Anyone, costs $10 a month for customers on
regional plan and $15 a month for national calling plan customers.
gives subscribers unlimited calling to 10 people who have service with Cingular Wireless, BellSouth, Vonage or other networks.
The rationale behind the brandless ads is to build curiosity and suspense.
It's form of interactive advertising, to get the public engaged in a guessing game.
But it's anyone's guess whether such ads succeed or get tuned out, said Bob Lauterborn, a professor of advertising at UNC-Chapel Hill.
Lauterborn hasn't seen
ads, but he says their effectiveness is dubious.
"There's this dopey assumption that people are watching your campaign and eagerly awaiting your next ad in the series," Lauterborn said.
"C'mon, people are too busy.
In today's world, people are not breathlessly waiting for your bloody ad."
